body: Can you be more specific in what's your alternative proposal?

I just think it doesn't make logical sense. If @piiswrong likes it, then I am fine, but why t bothers me is:
1) if SSE is supported, there's no reason not to use it, right? Why would anyone set USE_SSE to off?
2) SUPPORTS_SSE check is automatic. Why expose to the user/developer?   
3) The check will still occur, so USE_SSE doesn't seem to actually say whether SSE will be used. Settin gthe flag is superfluous, and per #1, you'd never turn it off manually anyway
4) Other PR can be changed. Why can;t it check the compiler flag in mshadow so that it doesn't require mshadow consumers to know that they must set this flag?
@piiswrong thank you. I will try it. If i succeed, i will update the answer.
OK, give me some time @chinakook

This sort of error doesn’t look familiar. What’s the difference in behavior of just letting the script finish rather than calling exit(0)? 
I’m not a python expert — does exit(0) cause a more immediate exit than reaching th end of the script? Is python shutdown procedure different?

I guess calling exit(0) before reaching the end changes the order in which objects are deleted. I can't reproduce the error without the exit statement, so leaving it out probably causes the "data" object to be  deterministically deleted before the _LIB handle, while when using exit(), the _LIB handle sometimes gets deleted before the "data" object, causing the errors seen.
I tried to use imagerecorditer, it will be ok, maybe its a bug in NDarray

@qiliux - I tried that but overall accuracies is going down. Also the number of negative images i need to increase but still the accuracies is not going up. Also the number of classes will increase (i meant need to put if-else condition; basically not to display). 
Is there any way to somehow lower down/increase the overtrained losses for each class by putting negative samples ? Or any research papers associated with this kind-of approach (did google but in vain)
Hi, I'm writing a custom stateful op in c++ using the new interface, but I can't find how to share the state of a forward op with its gradient partner. Any tips for solving this? Thanks
need I write it myself? if I use the same one as train ,it will output a disordered result
Ok, you convinced me. I will close this PR and fix mshadow to use SUPPORTS_SSE. I think it's better not to expose this additional flag as you say. Thanks for your review.

I had approximately the same issue and I've overcome it by initializing 1d vector along the axis I want to concatenate on and then slicing it off. Something like:

```
dumb = nd.array([1])
another = nd.array([1])
nd.concat(dumb, another, dim=0)
nd.slice(dumb, begin=(1, 0), end(2, 1), dim=0)
```
For me the use case was that I've had to construct the tensor in a loop, row by row and therefore I would want to initialize it empty at first (partially specifying the shape).
use "sample_weight" instead

I've ever have headache with this, but you can access the json of symbols to do that(for reference, in jupyter type "mx.viz.plot_network??").
Moreover, the 'a'/'b'/'c'/'fc' are not operators but feature maps so get_type would be not proper. For example: y = F(x), in which y is the result of operator F but not operator itself.
In MXNet, operator is represented by node in graph and ndarray(tensor) is represented by edge in graph. It's same with Tensorflow, So you can get type of nodes as following:
```python
   conf = json.loads(smb.tojson())
    nodes = conf["nodes"]
    hidden_nodes = set()
    for node in nodes:
        op = node["op"]
        name = node["name"]
        if op == "null" and looks_like_weight(node["name"]):
            hidden_nodes.add(node["name"])
        elif op == "null" and name == "data":
            node["meta"] = {}
            node["meta"]["rf"] = 1
            node["meta"]["stride"] = 1
            node["meta"]["offset"] = 0
        elif op == "Convolution" or op == "Pooling":
            ....

Same error here.

----------
I fixed it by change the crop offset of the last crop layer from 34 to 31 (according to the author's caffe github). I am now a little confused with the crop offset.

@piiswrong can you help me check if my thought is right? I try my own dataset, but i can't make the fcn work. The loss is always high.
And i met some problems:

Problem1:  
I think we put loss function outside of the Block when using gluon, am i right?
The net output is N\*C\*H\*W. But my data label is N\*1\*H\*W.
 `loss =mx.ndarray.SoftmaxOutput(output, label, multi_output=True)` won't work, if i don't add `multi_output=True`.

Problem2: How to evaluate the accuracy? I'm still finding materials.



```
from mxnet.gluon import nn

class FCN32s_VGG16(gluon.HybridBlock):
    def __init__(self, num_outputs, **kwargs):
        
        super(FCN_VGG16, self).__init__(**kwargs)
        self.num_outputs=num_outputs
        with self.name_scope():
            # VGG16 
            self.conv1_1 = nn.Conv2D(channels=64, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=100,activation="relu")
            self.conv1_2 = nn.Conv2D(channels=64, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.pool1 = nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2)
            
            self.conv2_1 = nn.Conv2D(channels=128, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv2_2 = nn.Conv2D(channels=128, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.pool2 = nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2)
            
            self.conv3_1 = nn.Conv2D(channels=256, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv3_2 = nn.Conv2D(channels=256, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv3_3 = nn.Conv2D(channels=256, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            
            self.pool3 = nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2)
            self.conv4_1 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv4_2 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv4_3 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.pool4 = nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2)
            
            self.conv5_1 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv5_2 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.conv5_3 = nn.Conv2D(channels=512, kernel_size=(3,3), padding=1,activation="relu")
            self.pool5 = nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2)

            self.conv6 = nn.Conv2D(channels=4096, kernel_size=(7,7),activation="relu")
            self.drop1 = nn.Dropout(.5)
            
            self.conv7 = nn.Conv2D(channels=4096, kernel_size=(1,1),activation="relu")
            self.drop2 = nn.Dropout(.5)
            
            self.conv8 = nn.Conv2D(channels=num_outputs, kernel_size=(1,1),activation="relu")
            
            self.deconv = nn.Conv2DTranspose(channels=num_outputs,kernel_size=(64,64),strides=(32,32))
            
    def hybrid_forward(self, F, x):
        #print('type(x): {}, F: {}'.format(
         #   type(x).__name__, F.__name__))
        #print(x.shape)

        x = self.conv1_1(x)
        x = self.conv1_2(x)
        x = self.pool1(x)
        x = self.conv2_1(x)
        x = self.conv2_2(x)
        x = self.pool2(x)
        x = self.conv3_1(x)
        x = self.conv3_2(x)
        x = self.conv3_3(x)
        x = self.pool3(x)
        x = self.conv4_1(x)
        x = self.conv4_2(x)
        x = self.conv4_3(x)
        x = self.pool4(x)
        x = self.conv5_1(x)
        x = self.conv5_2(x)
        x = self.conv5_3(x)
        x = self.pool5(x)

        x = self.conv6(x)
        x = self.drop1(x)
        x = self.conv7(x)
        x = self.drop2(x)
        x = self.conv8(x)
        x = self.deconv(x)
        # How to use softmax and Crop here?
#         x = F.slice_axis(x,axis=2,begin=12,end=372)
#         x = F.slice_axis(x,axis=3,begin=12,end=372)
#         x = F.softmax(data=x)
        #print("FF-shape: ",x.shape)
        return x
net = FCN32s_VGG16(2)
# net.hybridize()
#print(net.collect_params())
net.collect_params().initialize(mx.init.Xavier(magnitude=1.24),ctx=ctx)

trainer = gluon.Trainer(net.collect_params(), 'sgd', {'learning_rate': 1e-7,'momentum':0.99, 'wd': 0.005})
loss = gluon.loss.SoftmaxCrossEntropyLoss()
epochs = 10
smoothing_constant = .01

for e in range(epochs):
    for i, (data,label) in enumerate(train_data):
        with autograd.record():
            data = data.as_in_context(ctx)
            label = label.as_in_context(ctx)

            output = net(data)
            # Do i use loss function right?
            loss = mx.ndarray.SoftmaxOutput(output, label, multi_output=True)

        loss.backward()
        trainer.step(data.shape[0])
        curr_loss = nd.mean(loss).asscalar()
        moving_loss = (curr_loss if ((i == 0) and (e == 0))
                       else (1 - smoothing_constant) * moving_loss + smoothing_constant * curr_loss)
   
    print("Epoch %s. Loss: %s" % (e, moving_loss))
```

@cjolivier01
@piiswrong

Some progress:
We did some tests on c4.8xlarge. cpu utilization was limited to 200% for pip install mxnet --pre 0.11.xx. For 0.12 it was around 480%. It seems that the problem is mxnet with libgfortran3 will limit cpu usage. Docker should be the same issue since libgfortran3 is installed in docker.

We also tried to set OMP_NUM_THREADS=16,
That doesn't help solving the cpu utilization problem during inference.

@jinfagang it's defined in C++ layer as _contrib_MultiBoxPrior and injected into mxnet.contrib.ndarray as MultiBoxPrior during the mxnet startup, all operators from C++ space are loaded into front-end space during startup.
hi @stoneyang ,have you figured out this issue?
@zhenglaizhang i think this issue had been solved,can you close it?

This issue is arising because coreml converter uses older model api in order to work with mxnet models. The gluon model is saved in a file format which seems incompatible with that of the model api. There are two aspects of this problem. One: should model api be intelligent enough to load the gluon model (and/or vice-versa)? Secondly, how to make coreml converter be able to convert gluon models?

For first, I see the need for a wider discussion. Depending on the outcome, we can figure out the right way for the second.

To make problems a bit more tricky:
- when gluon saves the checkpoint/symbol, it doesn't store the softmax layer and it needs to be explicitly added.
- gluon's parameter's file don't explicitly call out aux vs args difference which the model api relies on.

Will try to create a github issue with wider discussion around it. Will keep this open for coreml-converter part though.

I am using PyCharm IDE, it says an error that MultiBoxPrior can not be load, I try to build it from source, but the same result. In the end I find that this class exactly can be load in terminal and can run. I think this is not IDE friendly. The contribute most API can not load from IDE such as PyCharm. In the end the SSD example give me another Error says mx.symbol has not attribute of contribute...... I have given it up.......

And if I want to contribute classification model, where should I put the code? just put the symbol in [https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification/symbols](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification/symbols)? beside the symbol code, I will change some code such as optimizer, should I push these code?

We have pre-built binary for ubuntu. Depending on the cuda version, you may choose from:
`mxnet-cu75`, `mxnet-cu80`, or `mxnet-cu90`.
You can then use `pip install --pre package_name` to install the package.

We plan to do this after the IO pipeline refactor, then we can test everything together

solved it, there was a bug in the definition of unet: I wasn't using all layers in the def forward function, thus some were not initialized.

can we merge this?
This issue disappear when I restart the training, will keep tracking of this behavior. Close the issue for now.

To be more precise - if we compare PyTorch and MxNet Gluon, https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/api/python/gluon.html#mxnet.gluon.nn.Activation
 it seems like we should be fine if we could implement some (for e.g. Python code) that adheres to this API and replace it in an existing model, but it seems that the block API currently doesn't accept any custom 'Activation' objects, only a string representation which is passed to the underlying C++ Activation implementation. 

Would it be useful to create APIs for easily passing Activation object subclasses to easily out and try out new without needing to rewrite full models? A contrib folder for Gluon could contain all the activations that do not have an efficient C++ implementation yet.

This seems relevant given that there have been solid incremental improvements in this area:
ELUs : https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.07289
SELUs: https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.02515
Swish : https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.05941

"ThreadedEngine will _deadlock_ after a fork because it is multithreaded" is NOT technically correct, IMHO, because the actual behavior is unpredictable and may or may not result in deadlock, depending on the use of locks.
0908 MKLML has one bug fix which is seg fault of convolution when filter size is greater than spatial domain. So, it might be good to upgrade.
Yes, it would be nice to have a constant symbol similar to `nd.array`

I guess this line takes up much time in benchmarking module API. This literally allocates a new memory space and deep copy `resized_img` to `image` in each iteration. You can time it and confirm.
```python
image = mx.io.DataBatch(data=(mx.nd.array(resized_img), ), label=(mx.nd.array(['1']),))
```

Is this line correct? `top1 = np.argmax(prob)`. `prob` is a `mx.nd.NDArray` type. I don't think a numpy function could accept that.

If libgfortran wasn't installed you won't be able to run mxnet that was installed from pip, which means you are either running an older version of mxnet that doesn't include libgfortran library (which means source code difference), or you're building from source (which means potential build config and dependency differences).

@eric-haibin-lin after i call mx.nd.waitall(), the memory increasing problem no longer exist, but speed is only 2.5samples/s; I think my former code just keeps pushing data into the backend engine, but the engine just can't process fast enough; so memory keeps increasing untils it crashes. now I think i just have to face that the fact that its speed can only reach 2.5samples/s, Thanks for the tips.

1. define a var in symbol
```
weight = mx.symbol.Variable(name="weight", lr_mult=0)
```
2. define a mixed initializer, init the weight by const ndarray
```
weight = mx.nd.ones((3))
initializer = mx.init.Mixed(['weight', '.*'], [mx.init.Constant(weight), xavier])

```

Does result match original paper?

@zhreshold Could you have a look?

Yes, it’s a staging system to performance test the core operators like elemwise_add() in C++. Previously it just ddnthenlegacy ops like ActivationOp. Haibin may use it for sparse (he would probably have to make modifications) and I want to use it to validate the OMP/non-OMP op and general tuning.
It basically infers inputs and outputs and builds backward pass, running one or both ways, without all of the engine noise muddling up vtune (for example). I also have an optimized version of SGMon I want to test.
@zhreshold
Fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/pull/200
Sample of new use of the code changes is core_op_runner_test.cc
So this is just benchmarking, not the actual performance improvement part yet

@Beanocean find where libcuda.so.1 is in your box and have it in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
libcuda.so.1 is from runtime cuda driver package
 http://www.diegoacuna.me/installing-cuda-8-on-ubuntu-16-04/
the cuda driver is installed via
sudo apt-get install nvidia-367
You need the access to the driver for the ability of running cuda kernels created from python (or perl) space.
Thank you @anirudh2290 !

For module api, timing it line by line does not reflect real time cost of each line since they execute async. If you want to get the time of creating `image`, you need to add `waitall()` before and after it and time it. 

Besides, you don't need to add `prob.wait_to_read()` since the following `asnumpy()` will do that for you.

You can also move creating `image` outside the loop for module api.

I add `prob.wait_to_read()` to explicitly show async part of module API. 
I don't want to put image creation outside the loop since it need to be execute on each new image.
(If I really want to properly time, I should add transform_image inside for loop.)
I will test with waitall() to see if it's the mxnet prediction or the image creation that take all the time.

You can use mean squared error(MSE) of the output and input.
